title: The wrong visa could cost researchers $400K in Indonesia
text:
"The potential application of its criminal articles, especially where there remains some uncertainty around what is in fact covered by a research visa (or how and when they need to be obtained) adds a degree of risk for foreign researchers seeking to engage with potential Indonesian counterparts," Mr Evans said.

The new law comes as the Morrison government seeks to rally support for the free trade agreement that was signed by the Australian and Indonesian trade ministers in March but is still to be ratified by either country.

A parliamentary committee is due to report on the wide-reaching deal, known as the Australia Indonesia Comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreement, by mid this month. Labor won't declare its position until the committee's report is tabled.

Universities have been a firm supporter of the IA-CEPA, which could build on the already substantial links between the education sectors in the two countries and open the way for an Australian university to establish a campus to help cater for the educational demands of Indonesia's growing middle class.

University researchers face stiff fines if they travel to Indonesia on a tourist visa. Shutterstock

Supporters of the free trade deal say the criminal penalties contained in Indonesia's new Law on the National System for Science and Technology are a setback.

Mandar Oak, associate professor of Economics at the University of Adelaide, was among the academics who wrote in favour of the IA-CEPA to the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties, saying the free trade agreement would enhance ongoing partnership and exchange in teaching and research.

“The introduction of these new penalties is certainly unfortunate timing. There is a big push underway to encourage researchers to work on joint projects with Indonesians.

"The Australian relationship with Indonesia is very deeply embedded but there always seems to be political or geopolitical issues cropping up," Associate Professor Oak said.

Emma Connors is The Australian Financial Review's new Indonesia correspondent. She takes up her position in Jakarta later in October.
description: Academics travelling to Indonesia need to pay careful attention to permit regulations after the introduction of criminal penalties for doing the wrong thing.
